Thanks Bill. Like I said, I did enjoy the history and meet and greet.=A0 I'=
m just offering food for thought, perhaps for a future show.

--- On Mon, 8=
/3/09, psi_research <vilhellm@...> wrote:

From: psi_research <vi=

nday, August 3, 2009, 2:22 PM






=A0




    
                  Hey than=
ks to Steve Hultay and the rest of the team for providing many of the files=
. In response to Rick, it was the desire of Frank and myself to play the au=
dio samples WITHOUT providing the name of the file to allow the listener to=
 make up their own mind. In fact, I specifically made a written request to =
the radio show which was copied to Frank on this and the reasons why. Their=
 response was this wasn't a blind evaluation of communication but rather a =
radio show meant to introduce Frank and his pioneering work in a personal w=
ay to the audience and allow listeners to hear swept tuned device files. It=
 wasn't the proper forum for an indepth study, it was meant to be a virtual=
 meet and greet between Frank and the Darkness Radio listeners. -Bill Murph=
y



--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com, "Rick" <rasterer@.. .> wrote:

>

> U=
nfortunately, the examples used were problematic.

> 

> You might notice t=
hey either played the EVP, then told the audience what the they were suppos=
ed to hear, and then played it again.  Or told the audience what they were =
supposed to hear first.  They never just played the sound (without the lead=
ing questions), and gave the audience some time to decide what it was sayin=
g on their own.

> 

> So while the history at the start was interesting, a=
ll the examples were, sadly, more examples of how people can fool themselve=
s with  pareidolia, than examples of spirit communications.

> 

> 

> Note=
 also, this also explains why prerecording noises, and using them later for=
 the source of a Q/A session, still works.  It's a tricky explanation when =
trying to explain how spirits are 'changing' the sounds at session time.  B=
ut it is an easy explanation that it wouldn't matter whether the sounds wer=
e live or recorded, if it was just people hearing what they wanted to hear.=


> 

> I realize that many people aren't out to prove anything, and that's=
 fine: but in this case, it seemed a point of the interview was to demonstr=
ate the efficacy of the box.  In this case it would be better to either sta=
te they do not expect their examples to be prove anything, or if they expec=
t to convince an audience, to use better testing of their results, and less=
 leading of the audience.

> 

> imho

> 

> 

> 

>
